content:
The "Youth Violence Prevention Act of 1999" includes provisions for expanding instant gun check capabilities, such as developing or expanding a State instant criminal background check system and improving criminal justice records. Section 509 of Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase the percentage to 6% and includes provisions for developing or expanding a State instant criminal background check system with limited access for firearm purchasers. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow the transfer of firearms by a person who is not a licensed dealer, with the purchaser's authorization. TITLE II--NONREFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF SAFE STORAGE DEVICES FOR FIREARMS

SEC. 201. NONREFUNDABLE CREDIT FOR PURCHASE OF SAFE STORAGE DEVICES FOR FIREARMS.

(a) In General.--Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a nonrefundable credit for the purchase of safe storage devices for firearms. The tax code allows a credit for qualified firearm safe storage device expenses up to $250 per year. Qualified expenses include trigger locks, secure cabinets, or other safety devices for firearm storage. The tax code allows a credit for qualified firearm safe storage device expenses up to $250 per year, including trigger locks, secure cabinets, or other safety devices for firearm storage. Additionally, the definition of a firearm is based on section 921(a)(3) of title 18, United States Code. Title III of the tax code mandates the purchase of safe storage devices for firearms, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1998. Additionally, it prohibits the manufacture of handguns without child safety locks. Manufacturing handguns in the US without child safety locks is prohibited, with a $5,000 fine for violations. The lock must prevent the firearm from being discharged. Judicial review can be sought within 60 days of receiving a fine notice. Manufacturing handguns in the US without child safety locks is prohibited, with a $5,000 fine for violations. Judicial review can be sought within 60 days of receiving a fine notice in any United States district court for de novo review of the decision. This provision does not apply to governmental entities. The terms "State", "handgun", and "Secretary" have specific meanings as defined in section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code. TITLE IV--CHILD FIREARM ACCESS PREVENTION

SEC. 401. CHILDREN AND FIREARMS SAFETY. Title IV of the document focuses on child firearm access prevention. The amendment to Section 921(a) of title 18 defines "secure gun storage or safety device" to include devices that prevent firearm operation without authorization. Section 922 of title 18 introduces prohibitions and penalties related to firearm storage and safety measures. The amendment to Section 921(a) of title 18 prohibits giving juveniles access to certain firearms, defining a juvenile as an individual under 18 years old. It prohibits keeping loaded firearms within premises accessible to juveniles. If a juvenile gains access to a firearm without permission and causes harm or displays it in public, they could face imprisonment, a fine, or both. Exceptions include using secure gun storage or being a peace officer or military member. The text discusses exceptions to penalties for juveniles accessing firearms, such as lawful self-defense, lack of expectation of juvenile presence, or unlawful entry. Licensed firearms dealers must include section 922(z) on required forms. Licensed dealers must include section 922(z) on required forms for prospective firearm transferees. This section does not preempt state laws aimed at preventing children from harming themselves or others with firearms.
